title: Angina
content:
Unstable angina is a sign of more severe heart disease and may lead to a heart attack. What happens in the future will depend on things such as:
  * how many of your arteries are affected by coronary artery disease
  * how severe the narrowing is
  * if you’ve had a heart attack before, and 
  * how well your heart is working to pump blood around your body.


Having coronary artery disease means you’re likely to have atherosclerosis in other arteries (eg, the arteries that supply your brain), so you’re at higher risk of having a stroke.
####  What support is available if I have angina? 
Sometimes it can be helpful to talk with someone who knows what it’s like to live with heart disease and angina. The [Heart Foundation(external link)](https://www.heartfoundation.org.nz/ "Open external link") has an [online directory of community-run support groups(external link)](https://www.heartfoundation.org.nz/your-heart/cardiac-rehab-and-heart-support-groups/heart-support-groups "Open external link") around the country that provide a way of connecting with others.
